questiontext.text: Let [startlatexinline ABC endlatexinline] be a right-angled triangle [startlatexinline B endlatexinline]. Determine the length of the side [startlatexinline AB endlatexinline]. You can use a calculator to solve this exercise. [startlatexinline BC=4 endlatexinline] cm [startlatexinline CA=5 endlatexinline] cm

generalfeedback.text: We use Pythogoras'theorem to determine the length of the side [startlatexinline AB endlatexinline].  As the triangle [startlatexinline ABC endlatexinline] is right-angled in [startlatexinline B endlatexinline], the hypotenuse of the triangle corresponds to the side [startlatexinline CA endlatexinline].  By Pythagoras's theorem, we have [startlatex AB^2+BC^2=CA^2. endlatex]  Using the values of the lengths of the known sides, we obtain [startlatex AB^2+4^2=5^2. endlatex]  We solve this equation by isolating [startlatexinline AB endlatexinline]:  [startlatex AB^2+16=25, endlatex] [startlatex AB^2=25-16=9, endlatex] [startlatex AB=\sqrt{9}=3. endlatex] Thus [startlatexinline AB=3 endlatexinline] cm

questiontext.text: Let [startlatexinline ABC endlatexinline] be a right-angled triangle [startlatexinline C endlatexinline]. Determine the length of the side [startlatexinline AB endlatexinline]. You can use a calculator to solve this exercise. [startlatexinline BC=8 endlatexinline] cm [startlatexinline CA=6 endlatexinline] cm

generalfeedback.text: We use Pythogoras'theorem to determine the length of the side [startlatexinline AB endlatexinline].  As the triangle [startlatexinline ABC endlatexinline] is right-angled in [startlatexinline C endlatexinline], the hypotenuse of the triangle corresponds to the side [startlatexinline AB endlatexinline].  By Pythagoras's theorem, we have [startlatex CA^2+BC^2=AB^2. endlatex]  Using the values of the lengths of the known sides, we obtain [startlatex 6^2+8^2=AB^2. endlatex]  We solve this equation by isolating [startlatexinline AB endlatexinline]:  [startlatex AB^2=36+64=100, endlatex] [startlatex AB=\sqrt{100}=10. endlatex]Thus [startlatexinline AB=10 endlatexinline] cm

questiontext.text: Let [startlatexinline ABC endlatexinline] be a right-angled triangle [startlatexinline A endlatexinline]. Determine the length of the side [startlatexinline CA endlatexinline]. You can use a calculator to solve this exercise. [startlatexinline AB=12 endlatexinline] cm [startlatexinline BC=15 endlatexinline] cm

generalfeedback.text: We use Pythogoras'theorem to determine the length of the side [startlatexinline CA endlatexinline].  As the triangle [startlatexinline ABC endlatexinline] is right-angled in [startlatexinline A endlatexinline], the hypotenuse of the triangle corresponds to the side [startlatexinline BC endlatexinline].  By Pythagoras's theorem, we have [startlatex CA^2+AB^2=BC^2. endlatex]  Using the values of the lengths of the known sides, we obtain [startlatex CA^2+12^2=15^2. endlatex]  We solve this equation by isolating [startlatexinline CA endlatexinline]:  [startlatex CA^2+144=225, endlatex] [startlatex CA^2=225-144=81, endlatex] [startlatex CA=\sqrt{81}=9. endlatex] Thus [startlatexinline CA=9 endlatexinline] cm

By Pythagoras's theorem, we have [startlatex AB^2+BC^2=CA^2. endlatex]  Using the values of the lengths of the known sides, we obtain [startlatex AB^2+60^2=65^2. endlatex]  We solve this equation by isolating [startlatexinline AB endlatexinline]:  [startlatex AB^2+3600=4225, endlatex] [startlatex AB^2=4225-3600=625, endlatex] [startlatex AB=\sqrt{625}=25. endlatex] Thus [startlatexinline AB=25 endlatexinline] cm

questiontext.text: Let [startlatexinline ABC endlatexinline] be a right-angled triangle [startlatexinline C endlatexinline]. Determine the length of the side [startlatexinline AB endlatexinline]. You can use a calculator to solve this exercise. [startlatexinline BC=16 endlatexinline] cm [startlatexinline CA=63 endlatexinline] cm

generalfeedback.text: We use Pythogoras'theorem to determine the length of the side [startlatexinline AB endlatexinline].  As the triangle [startlatexinline ABC endlatexinline] is right-angled in [startlatexinline C endlatexinline], the hypotenuse of the triangle corresponds to the side [startlatexinline AB endlatexinline].  By Pythagoras's theorem, we have [startlatex CA^2+BC^2=AB^2. endlatex]  Using the values of the lengths of the known sides, we obtain [startlatex 63^2+16^2=AB^2. endlatex]  We solve this equation by isolating [startlatexinline AB endlatexinline]:  [startlatex AB^2=3969+256=4225, endlatex] [startlatex AB=\sqrt{4225}=65. endlatex]Thus [startlatexinline AB=65 endlatexinline] cm

questiontext.text: Let [startlatexinline ABC endlatexinline] be a right-angled triangle [startlatexinline B endlatexinline]. Determine the length of the side [startlatexinline AB endlatexinline]. You can use a calculator to solve this exercise. [startlatexinline BC=60 endlatexinline] cm [startlatexinline CA=61 endlatexinline] cm

generalfeedback.text: We use Pythogoras'theorem to determine the length of the side [startlatexinline AB endlatexinline].  As the triangle [startlatexinline ABC endlatexinline] is right-angled in [startlatexinline B endlatexinline], the hypotenuse of the triangle corresponds to the side [startlatexinline CA endlatexinline].  By Pythagoras's theorem, we have [startlatex AB^2+BC^2=CA^2. endlatex]  Using the values of the lengths of the known sides, we obtain [startlatex AB^2+60^2=61^2. endlatex]  We solve this equation by isolating [startlatexinline AB endlatexinline]:  [startlatex AB^2+3600=3721, endlatex] [startlatex AB^2=3721-3600=121, endlatex] [startlatex AB=\sqrt{121}=11. endlatex] Thus [startlatexinline AB=11 endlatexinline] cm

questiontext.text: Let [startlatexinline ABC endlatexinline] be a right-angled triangle [startlatexinline C endlatexinline]. Determine the length of the side [startlatexinline BC endlatexinline]. You can use a calculator to solve this exercise. [startlatexinline AB=85 endlatexinline] cm [startlatexinline CA=84 endlatexinline] cm

generalfeedback.text: We use Pythogoras'theorem to determine the length of the side [startlatexinline BC endlatexinline].  As the triangle [startlatexinline ABC endlatexinline] is right-angled in [startlatexinline C endlatexinline], the hypotenuse of the triangle corresponds to the side [startlatexinline AB endlatexinline].  By Pythagoras's theorem, we have [startlatex BC^2+CA^2=AB^2. endlatex]  Using the values of the lengths of the known sides, we obtain [startlatex BC^2+84^2=85^2. endlatex]  We solve this equation by isolating [startlatexinline BC endlatexinline]:  [startlatex BC^2+7056=7225, endlatex] [startlatex BC^2=7225-7056=169, endlatex] [startlatex BC=\sqrt{169}=13. endlatex] Thus [startlatexinline BC=13 endlatexinline] cm
